displayed_text: Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: We got out of the car, I mean I couldn’t… Doctor: You felt it? Patient: Well I couldn’t step on it. I couldn’t walk up the step normally. I had to take the right leg up and take the right because if I try to go with this it’s just. Doctor: What’d you do in Alabama? Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I…

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: The good news is just so you hear it, is half the guys are cured at five years and then if you look ten years down – Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: - the line, nine out of ten guys are still alive if you go through the hormones and surgery, hormones and radiation, okay. Patient: Sure, uh hum. Doctor: You may be fighting prostate cancer, but you’re alive. Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective.

Patient: They’re there… Doctor: They’re there forever. Patient: Yep. Doctor: But if your PSA is zero and you feel good, it’s controlled. Patient: Okay, okay. Doctor: I’ll take control and we can ease up on the chemo or give you a holiday for several months and then homerun. Patient: Okay, okay. But it never will go in remission, it will never be gone? Doctor: Well remission’s a tough word in cancer. Patient: I know. Yeah, yeah. Doctor: Remission would imply that everything is gone and when you have scans that are never going to be right, it’s hard for me to say you’re in remission. Patient: Sure, sure. Doctor: So we use words like response. You know are you having a good response? Is it a durable response? Is it a complete response? Patient: Okay.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You have a nurse visit. Patient: Yeah, that’s a hormone shot and a follow up. And, just before that, I’m supposed to do a three month PSA for him, so. Doctor: Okay. And then, you have another appointment with him in April. Patient: That’s correct. Doctor: Well. You gotta decide. I don’t think you need to see both of us. (Pause) Patient: Because you – Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not with Dr. S_. Patient: I’m not going to get more radi— Doctor: So, you don’t necessarily need to keep seeing him. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. Just

Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, we talked about an MRI which would tell us more about your back to see if there's something in the middle of the bone that would be cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or we could look at a PET scan, which you know, PSA is over point seven. These PET scans can be pretty good about picking up things. And basically they're just looking at how tumors are growing and if they’re growing, then they light up. Patient: Right. Doctor: So that we can do one of those scans and see how much lights up. Usually what…I don't like these tests because they tend to find what's under the radar. Because we know there's disease- Patient: Right. Doctor: -because you have had surgery. You have had radiation? Patient: Oh yeah. Healthcare Professional: Mhmm. Doctor: So you've got a PSA, you've got disease. So knowing where it is doesn't necessarily help me now. Patient: Right.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up. Family Member: It went up. Yes. Doctor: From four to nine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?

Family Member: Out of the three which one would you recommend. Doctor: Well, let me tell you a little bit more about what what the clinical trials entail, because then I'll tell you what I think, based on our conversation last time to what we should look into first. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: So the two clinical trials one is called the MAP study. And I might have briefly mentioned this last time, this is a study of muscadine grapeseed extract. Family Member: Yes you did. Doctor: Yeah. So this is a study- is a randomized study for people with a particular genotype. So what that means is what what we know is that when some people take antioxidants like you know, these a lot like pomegranate or the muscadine grapeseed extract- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: - some people actually do have an improvement in their PSA, their PSA is go down and, but when we give it to everybody, we don't really see an effect. What we found is that there are probably people with a certain genotype, meaning that certain changes in their DNA, which are like totally normal, about a quarter of the population has this. Patient: Mm. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: Those people are more likely to respond, it seems. So with this trial is first we check your genotype. So that's step one. And then if you are the particular genotype, which, for the purposes of we'll just call it AA. Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: That means that you're eligible for the study-

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.agree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::agree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.agree: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::agree

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: But if something's obviously seen on an additional scan, you know, we have clinical studies that we could think about. Patient: Right. Doctor: So we have one study where folks you know less than three spots. And as long as one is in bone, we radiate pinpoint radiation, the spots that we see- Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: -and half the people get of medicine that goes in their bloodstream that goes to cancer in the bone. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so that would be something that you know, based on sort of, if we really think T12 is real or T3 is real, that could be something that we would send you off to the radiation doctors to have them talk about that trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Then we get the PET scan and it actually says, you know, you've got 123 plus 456, you know, that we think most of this is real, we can step back and watch a little bit longer until either declares itself a little bit more. Patient: Right. Doctor: Or just say hey, it's there. And then we have a couple studies where the current standard for the guy who shows up with multiple spots is to go on hormones for life. Patient: Right.

Patient: So, I don’t need this, right? Doctor: No. Show them this paperwork, but show them that, I was gonna say, show them that so that you make sure they cancel and give you a new one. Okay. But anyway, that’s fine. Patient: I’ll, I’ll Doctor: Show them this paperwork, and then they’ll give you all of those appointments. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Let me go work on your scripts, and I’ll be back. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I ain’t gotta take no shots, no hip shots, or Doctor: You are due for your Lupron. So, Patient: Which one is that? Doctor: The hormone. The Lupron shot.

Family Member: Oh, I see. Doctor: I think that’s a little more unusual gene. So. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: So, whether that’s what it is -- Family Member: It affected pregnancy. So, that’s why it was in our family, but also Doctor: Did they test her children or anything or? Family Member: Uh, no she doesn’t have children. Patient: She doesn’t have children. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: She couldn’t. That’s part of the issue. Doctor: Okay. Family Member: It’s a blood thing, too. So, um. Doctor: It’s, it’s a gene that affects the body’s ability to use folate. (Pause)

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because, obviously, if today’s PSA keeps on going up, we need to look and see what’s going on. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay? And, chances we are going to have to put you on a medication called Zytiga. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. This is a pill. These are pills that have a very good chance of working against the cancer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And they will likely shrink the disease and, you know, also lower the PSA, and the good thing is they are likely to work for long periods of time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But, the possibility of side effects is a little bit higher. Okay? And usually, those side effects are high blood pressure, leg swelling, low potassium. So, you’re going to have to monitor and stay with the visits because at least for the first few months, we’ll have to monitor you somewhat closer. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Once both of us sort of get comfortable, like we did, but you got too comfortable, Doctor: With this medication

Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um okay. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: I had a CT scan Doctor: Yeah Patient: this morning and we asked for a stat read, but it… Doctor: Yeah. That’s the one. Patient: Okay. Wow. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m reading Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. VIP apparently you are. Patient: Well, probably. Doctor: Well we said we just really need to know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know so we’re we’re doing the whole we gotta come up with the next study uhh situa - and the good part is there’s more trials that opened up. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So on the clinical study, we do scan him more than he would get if he was not on the clinical trial because we’re giving you more therapy than what’s usual, and they wouldn’t want us to keep giving you drugs that they’re not helping, and so they They want the actual data about scans. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So that would be a potential good thing for you. If you want more information, the study gives you more of that information. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But how I make decisions, I don’t necessarily need those scans. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I want to make sure on the studies everybody gets pictures of the same time points so that we can see when the cancer changes. Patient: And another question that I have. At one point we talked to acupuncturist and he said he can help through acupuncture with peeing problems. So and I was thinking we’d go on the day when we take the catheter our, but now I’m thinking maybe I should wait. And now if that is okay, see if that may be some additional help. Doctor: I don’t know. I think it’s reasonable to try. You know most acupuncturists will ask you about your current situation – Patient: Right. Doctor: - and see how well it would help. You know my worry is you know if you’re spending money on that then how does it help? You know if they are doing it and you get the catheter out is it because of my drug or because they gave you, you know acupuncture and how long you paid them?

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They -
